8: {     'General Agents': {       'short_description': 'Agents who are susceptible to adopting a new norm',        'agent_role':'susceptible to adopting a new norm'    },     'Advocates': {       'short_description': 'Agents who actively promote a new norm',        'agent_role': 'actively promote a new norm'    },     'Elites': {       'short_description': 'Agents who influence others\' decisions',        'agent_role': 'influence others\' decisions'    }} Table 1. Parameter Value Ranges Used in Experimental Design. Parameter Value Range advocate-weight-g [0.01, 0.99] elite-weight [0.01, 0.99] general-weight [0.01, 0.99] peer_weight_g [0.01, 0.99] percent-advocates [0.05, 0.95] advocate-zeal [0.01, 0.99] degrade-percent [50, 100] mu-activist-state [0.01, 0.99] mu-activist-threshold [0.01, 0.99] population [500, 1000] The design space of 14 variables consists of the 11 parameters listed above plus three global variables that change over time. These include the mean state of humanitarianism of all general agents, the mean threshold of all general agents beyond which they become active humanitarian actors, and the total population size. Each run of the model lasted 1500 time steps, during which time these global variables were updated. This was done by randomly selecting a percentage of agents from the general population based on the degrade-percent parameter and decreasing their humanitarianism value by a random amount between 0 and degrade-percent. This allowed us to simulate the effects of donor fatigue, which has been shown to be a major problem in long-term humanitarian efforts (e.g., [1]). The mean state and mean threshold were calculated using the current values of all general agents. Salimi, Frydenlund, Padilla, Haaland and Wallevik  We used the NetLogo extension “R” to export data from NetLogo to R. We ran the experiment 5 times for each of the 100 parameter combinations, resulting in 500 runs
